overview: This subject introduces some of the key principles and approaches of working with young people in relation to mental health. The subject will also introduce the key theories and research that underlie contemporary understandings of young people and mental health.

• The need for service reform in the mental health sector
  • Understanding youth and mental health
  • Aetiological models of youth mental ill-health
  • Impact of mental ill-health on young people
  • Early intervention in youth mental health
  • Barriers and enablers in youth mental health
  • Youth-friendly service delivery
ilo: Outline the rationale for adapting mental health services to the needs of young people aged 12 to 25
Explain important concepts and models surrounding the relationship between youth and mental health
Identify common factors contributing to mental ill-health in young people
Describe the impact of mental ill-health on young people
Identify barriers and enablers that influence young people's access to mental health services
Distinguish the key approaches that underlie youth-friendly service provision
generic_skills: Capacity to translate knowledge into practice

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Online Quizzes of learning content – two multiple choice quizzes with 10 questions each = 20 questions in total (1% per question)
Graded discussion board – posting fortnightly reflections on learning content and responding to fellow students, with a minimum of 7 posts in total

date_times.contact_hours: Online equivalent to 20 contact hours is made up of 10 hours of lectures and live consultation sessions, and 10 hours of asynchronous discussions and structured online tasks.
